Greetings, I’m Karl Meitinger! Welcome to Munich in 1955!

As you might know, during the Second World War I already imagined how we could rebuild this city after the Nazis regime has ended. Then, almost ten years ago, I presented my vision to the city council and they were delighted. They agreed to my plans right away!

But as you can imagine, rebuilding an entire city is a lot of work. Right now we are rebuilding the Old Town Hall piece by piece. We already started working on it a little bit, to keep it from falling on peoples’ heads. It was truly a mess after the war, just look at those pictures:
$picture
$picture
Just this year, we had the money to rebuild the gable facades almost like they were in 1936.
$picture

It was magnificent back then! Unfortunately, we did not find those spires that you can see on top of the roof yet. But just yesterday I heard that someone spotted them on the Maxburghalde! That’s in front of the Old Maxburg where we collect the rubble from destroyed buildings from the center. Will you come and help me find the spires?
Oh no, looks like we need to dig a bit! No use wasting time…
Hm. Looks like this building also paid a tribute to the war. But I think Sep Ruf and Theo Pabst already have plans on integrating the tower in a new building here.
Let’s collect the spire and move on to our next task…
So, place the spire on the façade to see how it fits!
Looks quite good! We can repair this and make some more to replace the ones you didn’t find!
Our next task is to redecorate the big hall on the first level! If you walk underneath the Town Hall and look up, you can see right into it!
Right, let's place the spire on the façade and see how it fits!
Oh no, looks like we need to clear away some rubble! No use wasting time...
Collect the iron rods.

Oh oh! Looks like these buildings also paid a tribute to the war. Didn't we find some iron rods before? We can use those and stabilize the parts that have not broken down yet.I think Sep Ruf and Theo Pabst already have plans on building something new here, anyways.
Ok, let’s collect the spire and then we’re good to go. But, since we’re already on the move, let’s make a quick stop at the Stadtmuseum.

You know, we’re simultaneously rebuilding the famous Grand Hall on the inside of the Old Town Hall. Much of its interior decoration was lost. But luckily the most famous wooden figures in there, from 1480, were put into the museum long before. Only replicas of the morris dancers were destroyed. Currently, we’re thinking about putting back the originals, however.
Here we are. Look, the curator already placed the dancers out for us. So nice of him!
You know, it’s a pity. The carpenter who made these, made 16 different figures, once. Unfortunately, six of them were lost during the centuries so only these ten remain. Let’s collect them.

Before heading back, you might want to take a look around this square. Before the war, the main synagogue of Munich was actually placed right next to the Maxburg. But after its destruction, it was decided to build one here instead, right next to a Jewish Museum.
Let’s walk around the Synagogue once!
